awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies what allows underrepresented groups to break glass ceilings in (1) becoming professors and (2) the reception of their innovative ideas.  Women, minorities, and international students become professors at significantly lower rates than their counterparts. Even if they become professors, their scientific innovations may be received differently than those of others. These glass ceilings are studied by investigating the factors that affect whether over 1.2 million US doctoral recipients (1977-2015) become professors, and whether they become professors with long lineages of subsequent students who go on to become faculty themselves.  Also studied is whether diverse individuals bring new concepts and new conceptual relations and expand the body of research in new directions.  The project also examines factors that affect the citation and reception of research (net of its contribution), with attention to the work of diverse scholars.  Findings will show how barriers to diversity in higher education may be lowered and overcome and what policy levers can be used to enable equal access to the professoriate and to the creation of scholarly ideas, to the benefit of science and the national welfare more generally. This project was supported jointly by the Education and Human Resources Core Research Program, the Sociology Program, and Science of Broadening Participation. 

Going beyond previous studies, this project follows doctoral recipients and their careers and considers all scientific fields and multiple demographic groups.  The data for this study encompass almost all scientists that entered US academia from 1977-2015.  The anchor data set of degree recipients is augmented by data on their authoring activities and enriched by demographic data, academic field, and citations.  Questions relating to innovation are investigated by extracting data concerning the content of publications.  Following linking of the various data sets and cross-validation, statistical analyses are used to investigate the principal questions of the study.  Contributions of the study include data to be publicly available, methods for processing and analyzing similar data, and findings concerning the glass ceilings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Enduring inequalities arise in educational systems when barriers to mobility and recognition exist. However, there is little research on the factors that lead PhDs to transition into the professoriate. Prior work in this area conducts careful qualitative case studies; focuses on a single group, program, or field; or focuses only on successful professors and asking what qualities they share in common. Using these prior works as a springboard, we greatly expand the focus to concern the careers of over 1 million US PhDs from 1980-2015. Most of these never become professors or have their work recognized, but by studying them and their careers, we are able to identify factors facilitating successful transitions over those features which do not. In so doing, we come to see how underrepresented individuals experience chilly climates, leaky pipelines and glass ceilings that prevent their upward mobility, and what resilience and supportive factors enable them to overcome these challenges. 

In several studies, we find (for all fields), underrepresented individuals are more likely to generate novel ideas and intellectual connections, but these contributions are not recognized at the same rate as white and male students? equivalent contributions. In addition, we find that even when underrepresented students contribute an equally recognized novel idea, the returns to the underrepresented student are less than that to the white and male student. We partly explain this inequity as the result of the nature of the intellectual contributions diverse students make ? they are often distal connections unfamiliar to the core and dominant set of researchers of scientific fields. We also find that these distally related contributions take longer to be recognized, but that over time, they do get taken up. In short, this suggests that minority students make valuable novel intellectual contributions, but because they are less interpretable to the majority groups dominating a field, they take longer to become core concepts of a research field. The implication of these findings is that greater translation may be needed to render minority contributions more relatable. And /or it may help to explain that distal discoveries will be where their fields move over time anyway so they should reconsider whether their positional bias may be preventing them from seeing their long-term value (Galvez et al 2019; Hofstra et al 2020; Heiberger et al 2021; Schiebinger et al 2021). 

Some other work of ours finds that underrepresented scholars still face implicit and explicit bias that may thwart the diversification of the professoriate and the broadened representation of different groups research ideas. In particular, women find their research topics are devalued by mere association with women authors, and this effect is over and above the effect of structural barriers women face. As such, it helps to study man-dominated topics like machine learning over woman-dominated topics like child development, and even within sociology, it helps to study say causal methods over sociology of education. Interestingly, women in STEM fields face more explicit bias in the form of access and structural barriers, while women in the Humanities and Social Sciences (HSS) have greater access and representation in their fields but face more implicit bias in the sense that what they study is devalued. These findings suggest more work is needed to make hiring committees and universities aware of these biases that may be preventing women from reaching the highest levels of the professoriate (Kim et al 2021). 

Last, we explored a variety of different mentoring relations that better enable minority and women students to enter the professoriate and sustain their research careers. We looked at whether advisors are accomplished, have experience mentoring students, have available time to mentor students, show prior success with students, have shared interests with their students, and come from the same backgrounds as their students. In addition, we looked at the makeup of the faculty available to mentor students. Controlling for many other confounding factors, we find that the diversity of faculty helps minorities and women PhDs better reach a professor role, but not enough to catch up with their white and male peers. To be more on par with white and male students, minority and women PhDs require a specific kind of mentoring relation: that of a same attribute mentor. Upon careful examination, we find this is the key contributor to diversifying the professoriate because same-attribute advisors have some familiarity with the difficulties their underrepresented students encounter. Moreover, we find whites and males chances of career success are not diminished by association with different race and gender peers. All this suggests hiring diverse faculty is key, and so is learning from these faculty what it is they experienced, know, and impart to their minority and women students that is of such great value. In such a fashion, other groups of advisors can become better mentors to underrepresented students (Hofstra et al).
